category_summary:
**OpenAI** dominated discussions with a historic monetization shift: [ads coming to **ChatGPT**](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-ee08e8631101) free and new Go ($8/month) tiers. **Sam Altman** outlined principles promising ads won't influence responses, while also [teasing 'very fast Codex'](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-d29dc9dbdc9b) and [confirming memory improvements](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-3c27231aee96) via **Greg Brockman**.

- **Demis Hassabis** announced **TranslateGemma** open translation models for edge devices, outperforming larger models
- **Jerry Liu** (LlamaIndex founder) sparked debate [declaring 'chunking is dead'](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-a93b19cd93ef) as agents dynamically handle file context
- **Ethan Mollick** argued AI agents have [crossed an inflection point](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-cec75caa54ce) for real workplace impact
- Explosive historical drama: Altman revealed **Elon Musk** [demanded majority equity](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-b283e00162e7) and his children controlling AGI during OpenAI's founding

**Cowork** [availability for Pro](/?date=2026-01-17&category=social#item-85fd04203bf8) users generated massive excitement (103K views), signaling growing appetite for integrated agent workflows.

items.title:
We are starting to test ads in ChatGPT free and Go (new $8/month option) tiers.

Here are our princi...
items.content:
We are starting to test ads in ChatGPT free and Go (new $8/month option) tiers.

Here are our principles. Most importantly, we will not accept money to influence the answer ChatGPT gives you, and we keep your conversations private from advertisers.

It is clear to us that a lot of people want to use a lot of AI and don't want to pay, so we are are hopeful a business model like this can work.

(An example of ads I like are on Instagram, where I've found stuff I like that I otherwise never would have. We will try to make ads ever more useful to users.)

In the coming weeks, we plan to start testing ads in ChatGPT free and Go tiers.

Weâ€™re sharing our principles early on how weâ€™ll approach adsâ€“guided by putting user trust and transparency first as we work to make AI accessible to everyone.

What matters most:
- Responses in ChatGPT will not be influenced by ads.

- Ads are always separate and clearly labeled.

- Your conversations are private from advertisers.

- Plus, Pro, Business, and Enterprise tiers will not have ads.

I remembered a lot of this, but here is a part I had forgotten:

"Elon said he wanted to accumulate ...
items.content:
I remembered a lot of this, but here is a part I had forgotten:

"Elon said he wanted to accumulate $80B for a self-sustaining city on Mars, and that he needed and deserved majority equity. He said that he needed full control since heâ€™d been burned by not having it in the past, and when we discussed succession he surprised us by talking about his children controlling AGI."

I appreciate people saying what they want and think it enables people to resolve things (or not). But Elon saying he wants the above is important context for Greg trying to figure out what he wants.

items.title:
Interesting social media job: What if your product doesn't fit the narrative?

@sundayrobotics is in...
items.content:
Interesting social media job: What if your product doesn't fit the narrative?

@sundayrobotics is in that spot, and needs a storyteller to help find and feed customers. 

It isn't a full humanoid. It can't walk up stairs.

It doesn't have hands that can deal cards, or play ping pong.

It isn't able to run on the street like @Figure_robot or do Kung Fu or dance next to humans, like we have seen many of the Chinese ones. 

@adcock_brett will never compare his robot to it (robot entrepreneurs tell me that their biggest days so far were when Brett fights with them, which causes the X algorithm to push the fight to everyone's feed).

@cixliv will never buy one to fight in his robot fights. 

It doesn't have a chance against @elonmusk and his Optimus. The founder of Sunday isn't someone that has a huge social media platform, or, even a name you would recognize. Heck, I had dinner with him last week at CES and I barely remember his name. Tony something. 

Taking this job running social media for Sunday would be torture. It looks goofy. It doesn't cause people to dream. I doubt it ever will go viral, even though it got a nice bump from the AI industry when it was first revealed. 

It isn't sexy. It doesn't fit the narrative.

It'd be like eating glass, forcing the narrative here on X and other places to generate hype will be horrible. 

Yet I'm intrigued, I must like eating glass. 

Why?

Because its approach has a good potential customer base. 

25% of US adults have bad knees. 

My best friend is one of them. 

That's 65 million. Huge TAM (total addressable market).

My friend can't stand for long. Soon will have knee replacement, but even then he'll probably have a tough time bending over to pick a sock off the floor that he dropped.

But here's the rub: he can't afford a @1x_tech NEO. Or a Figure. Or a Tesla Optimus. All of which are expected to be $20,000, or more. 

He also doesn't need a robot that can dance, fight, or play ping pong. 

He just needs a little extra help around the home. Picking up socks. Bringing him a remote. Putting dishes in the sink. Maybe someday an Optimus or a Neo will get cheap enough that he can have one of those wash the dishes, but let's be honest those days are years away. 

Sunday's approach should bring us a robot for much less money than all those others. And, because it is on wheels, should have other advantages, like battery life, and safety. Plus it will be easier to manufacture than any of those others, so will be more likely to be in his home sooner than any of those others.

At CES last week I saw two of the Chinese humanoids fall. A wheeled approach should never fall. And having legs and standing takes quite a bit of power where wheels use a lot less.

So, someone who takes this social media job will have to be skilled at something that few are: finding customers and positioning. 

What would I do if I had this job?

Admit its limitations. And turn those into the brand. 

Page Alloo, one of the world's top positioning geniuses, taught me this (I worked for her partner and helped her a bit with her computers). 

Turn the positives into a negative. Turn the negatives into a positive, she would tell me.

What are the positives?

Two fingered hands (grippers) can do a lot. And are far cheaper, and are more reliable, than the hands that can play ping pong. 

The @SharpaRobotics hands we all were wowed by at CES cost about $50,000. Now, yeah, they will come down in cost someday, but not in 2026. They are too hard to make, require too many computers to deal with the data from having 1,000 sensors in each finger (and a camera in the palm). 

Plus, there is how it looks. A humanoid brings many expectations. I watched dozens of people hug the Neo, including AI genius @karpathy. No one will feel impelled to hug the Sunday. It looks like one of those Playmobile toys I used to love playing with as a kid.

If my friend had one of these in his home, moving around, I wouldn't feel like it would have super human capabilities, or want to hug it, or talk to it. It'd be just like his refrigerator, just a piece of technology that is there, but won't bring crazy expectations, like I will have when an Optimus arrives. When that comes it better play some ping pong with me. 

This is why Sunday caught my attention. They are taking shitty hardware and making it do a lot of things with AI innovations. 

Now, the question for whoever gets this job, can he or she get through the algorithm? I don't believe so. You need to have a robot that can run, dance, fight, entertain, or do Kung Fu to do that. 

So, most of their effort should be to find communities of people with bad knees who need a little extra help around the house. 

Maybe do a community, newsgroup, discord channel, etc for people with bad knees, or have other problems bending over to pick socks off of the floor (paralyzed people, for instance, who are waiting in line to get a Neuralink). And who aren't wealthy enough to buy one with hands with 10 fingers. 

That can keep to the message and avoid getting in fights with Elon or Brett? 

Are you someone who can do that? Who can find people around people like that who can help them see the value in such a robot? 

And maybe find more investors who see the value in such an approach?

Then this job is for you.

items.title:
ðŸš¨ ChatGPT is bringing ads to the platform. 

We knew it was coming.

Here's what you need to know:  ...
items.content:
ðŸš¨ ChatGPT is bringing ads to the platform. 

We knew it was coming.

Here's what you need to know:  
â†’ Ads appearing for free and Go tier users only 
â†’ Plus, Pro, and Enterprise subscriptions stay ad-free 
â†’ Ads will appear at the bottom of responses
â†’ Ads will be clearly labeled 
â†’ Ads do not influence the answers ChatGPT gives you
â†’ No user data sold to advertisers 
â†’ No ads for users under 18 
â†’ No ads on sensitive topics (health, politics, mental health)

In Oct 2024, Altman spoke at HBS and answered an audience question about monetization saying that: he hates ads, it misaligns the customer with the service, and that they were a last resort if it meant getting more people access to the best AI (and that he wasn't totally against them). He said "ads plus AI is uniquely unsettling" to him. 

The essential product with all of these platforms (ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, Perplexity, Copilot, etc) is trust. I'll be watching how this rollout affects growth, revenue, profit, pay tiers, and adoption of course. But mostly, I'll be watching the impact on user experience and trust by generation and region, and whether other players follow the freemium-to-ads model. 

Read more here: https://t.co/AXznLh6c0B

items.title: I was working with a team right before the holidays. I was helping them fix some AI-induced mess the...
items.content:
I was working with a team right before the holidays. I was helping them fix some AI-induced mess they created.

To be honest, they didn't have an AI problem. Their issue was rushing to integrate Claude Code on an existing codebase with no tests, no CI/CD, and very poor documentation.

It was also a very large codebase.

This is one of those situations where I'm very cautious about Claude Code: you can't bring it into a large, complex codebase and expect it to just work.

Many people think that agentic coding made engineering principles useless.

It didn't.

Good engineering practices didn't become less important because of AI. They actually became the difference between AI being a liability and a force multiplier.

Without a good foundation, AI will just help you ship garbage faster.

The companies that will continue crushing it with AI are those that already have solid engineering practices in place.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Pino shares cautionary tale about a team that integrated Claude Code into a large codebase lacking tests, CI/CD, and documentation, emphasizing that good engineering practices are even more important with AI - they're the difference between AI being a liability vs force multiplier

items.title:
File *interfaces are all you need 

It is such a powerful abstraction for coding agents to dynamical...
items.content:
File *interfaces are all you need 

It is such a powerful abstraction for coding agents to dynamically search a file. A classic problem with a "static" chunk/embed static is that the agent doesn't have complete context on the source document. 

Today, all the latest coding agents are able to dynamically jump between different content sections within a file to find what they need; and the models are lightweight/tuned enough on agentic reasoning to pull in way more dynamic context.

The only missing layer is doing OCR to convert non-plaintext formats like PDFs, Powerpoints into plaintext ones that LLMs can understand
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu argues file interfaces are the key abstraction for coding agents - models can dynamically search files, making static chunking/embedding obsolete. OCR for non-plaintext formats is the missing layer
items.reasoning: Detailed technical insight from LlamaIndex founder about modern coding agent architectures and retrieval patterns
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu argues file interfaces are the key abstraction for coding agents - models can dynamically search files, making static chunking/embedding obsolete. OCR for non-plaintext formats is the missing layer
items.content_html:
File *interfaces are all you need

It is such a powerful abstraction for coding agents to dynamically search a file. A classic problem with a "static" chunk/embed static is that the agent doesn't have complete context on the source document.

Today, all the latest coding agents are able to dynamically jump between different content sections within a file to find what they need; and the models are lightweight/tuned enough on agentic reasoning to pull in way more dynamic context.

The only missing layer is doing OCR to convert non-plaintext formats like PDFs, Powerpoints into plaintext ones that LLMs can understand

items.title:
Ok clarifying some comments here so that this is not entirely clickbait: 

- RAG is so loosely defin...
items.content:
Ok clarifying some comments here so that this is not entirely clickbait: 

- RAG is so loosely defined right now you could call any retrieval RAG. i was referring to file search replacing "naive" RAG as in chunk, embed, put into vector db as the only form of retrieval 
- You *obviously* need a database / better persistence layer especially as # of files scales and you want to build your app in production. 
- Backing your data in a prod db is probably better than only spinning up arbitrary e2b file boxes
- What is unclear though is how that persistence layer is designed. Is a SQL db just a metadata layer that poitns to the file content? Vector search is still nice, but you can decouple initial retrieval from the final context the LLM sees during generation, if you just give the LLM access to the entire file. 

---------

What I really wanted to highlight though is the *unreasonable effectiveness* of 
1. the file interface
2. file search operations

Having a file tool interface allows the agent to dynamically scroll up and down a file, which eliminates the need to worry about chunking at all. 

Using simple file search like `ls` and `grep` is unreasonably effective up to a few hundred docs. And you don't really need a db at that scale. At higher scales, I'd be curious to see how we can combine the file interface with a more scalable search/persistence layer.
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex founder) clarifies his RAG comments: argues 'naive RAG' (chunk/embed/vector DB) is being replaced by file interfaces that let agents dynamically scroll files, combined with simple operations like ls and grep that work well up to hundreds of docs
items.reasoning: Deep technical insight from LlamaIndex creator on evolving RAG architectures. Challenges conventional wisdom about vector DBs being necessary at smaller scales. Good engagement (110 likes).
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex founder) clarifies his RAG comments: argues 'naive RAG' (chunk/embed/vector DB) is being replaced by file interfaces that let agents dynamically scroll files, combined with simple operations like ls and grep that work well up to hundreds of docs
items.content_html:
Ok clarifying some comments here so that this is not entirely clickbait:

  • RAG is so loosely defined right now you could call any retrieval RAG. i was referring to file search replacing "naive" RAG as in chunk, embed, put into vector db as the only form of retrieval
  • You *obviously* need a database / better persistence layer especially as # of files scales and you want to build your app in production.
  • Backing your data in a prod db is probably better than only spinning up arbitrary e2b file boxes
  • What is unclear though is how that persistence layer is designed. Is a SQL db just a metadata layer that poitns to the file content? Vector search is still nice, but you can decouple initial retrieval from the final context the LLM sees during generation, if you just give the LLM access to the entire file.

---------

What I really wanted to highlight though is the *unreasonable effectiveness* of

1. the file interface

2. file search operations

Having a file tool interface allows the agent to dynamically scroll up and down a file, which eliminates the need to worry about chunking at all.

Using simple file search like `ls` and `grep` is unreasonably effective up to a few hundred docs. And you don't really need a db at that scale. At higher scales, I'd be curious to see how we can combine the file interface with a more scalable search/persistence layer.

items.title: I tested Claude Code with an API key where you pay for tokens. Every code update request for my apps...
items.content:
I tested Claude Code with an API key where you pay for tokens. Every code update request for my apps costs about $0.80 in token cost.

I make a couple hundred requests every day with my Max subscription ($100/month). If I paid for tokens, that would cost me around $80/day. So, Claude sells Max about 30 times cheaper than it sells Opus to third parties.

There's no way a third-party IDE company without its own Claude Opus-like model can provide a competing agentic coding service to Anthropic.

Cursor? Are you kidding me?

items.title: This week, we released a pair of Gemma updates that developers can use to innovate across the health...
items.content:
This week, we released a pair of Gemma updates that developers can use to innovate across the healthcare and translation spaces: 

â€” MedGemma 1.5 4B: Our updated open medical AI model improves performance in 3D imaging and reasoning over medical records. We also kicked off the MedGemma Impact Challenge on @Kaggle to inspire development of AI applications that can help patients 
â€” TranslateGemma: This collection of multimodal open translation models is built on Gemma 3 and enables developers to build translation tools across 55 language pairs. The models are efficiently compact (available in 4B, 12B, and 27B parameter sizes), achieving high-fidelity translation quality with lower latency

You can access both Gemma models on @huggingface, MedGemma on Vertex AI, and TranslateGemma on Kaggle. To learn more about Gemma and our latest breakthroughs from @GoogleDeepMind, visit https://t.co/Mf9nPsX2vA!

items.title:
The robotics inflection point is here.

I reconnected with Spencer Huang, @nvidia's Product Lead for...
items.content:
The robotics inflection point is here.

I reconnected with Spencer Huang, @nvidia's Product Lead for Robotics at #CES. His take: companies winning in robotics have stopped waiting for perfect AI models.
They're building data infrastructure NOW.

Three critical moves for 2026:
1. Build the data flywheel â†’ Curate real data, generate quality synthetic data. "It's very easy to generate lots of data that's not useful."
2. Target hybrid tasks â†’ The sweet spot: too complex for traditional robots, not complex enough to need full general AI. Deploy today.
3. Leverage dual simulation â†’ #Cosmos for diversity. 
#Omniverse for physics. Together they unlock infinite scenarios with accuracy.

The winners won't have the best models. They'll have the best data. Is your data infrastructure ready for the #robotics era?

Full interview: https://t.co/CKl2xbAYku

#Robotics #AI #NVIDIAPartner

items.content_html:
@jamesmurray @MikeIsaac A friend of mine put it better.

Google is a peer of Apple's. And isn't disruptive. Known quantity. And already is a partner of Apple's. OpenAI could be far more disruptive, and dishonest (even its founding is clearly dishonest).

Google hasn't been able to make a pair of headphones that anyone cares about, and even its pixel phones haven't eaten away at Apple's core customer base.

items.title: Our mission these days is digitalizing paperwork ðŸ“„, and a lot of paperwork has handdrawn stuff - lik...
items.content:
Our mission these days is digitalizing paperwork ðŸ“„, and a lot of paperwork has handdrawn stuff - like highlights!

If you upload a scanned form into LlamaParse, you can add a simple prompt to output all highlighted text with html tags. This is reflected in both the raw markdown and the preview. It helps you capture what the human annotator cared about, which is helpful for automating downstream extraction, or as additional context for LLMs/agents.

You can get these results directly through our agentic mode. Just append â€œoutput highlighted text with special html tagsâ€ and youâ€™re all set.

Sign up: https://t.co/QwzurFBE67

items.title: @EmCeeH0 @PeterDiamandis @TonyRobbins That just isn't true. You really need to visit San Francisco a...
items.content:
@EmCeeH0 @PeterDiamandis @TonyRobbins That just isn't true. You really need to visit San Francisco and see what's happening on the streets: Waymos, Zooxs, and soon Teslas are everywhere. 

They are taking jobs, and they're going to come for a lot more jobs over the next three years. It's only going to accelerate from here. It might have taken a little bit of time to get here, but it's here now, and it's not just hype. 

I've been interviewing Waymo customers, and they tell me over and over:
1. "I'm never buying a car again."
2. "I'm never driving again."
3. "I'm never taking an Uber again."
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer reports firsthand observations of autonomous vehicles in San Francisco (Waymo, Zoox), claiming job displacement is real and accelerating. Cites customer feedback: 'never buying a car again,' 'never driving again,' 'never taking Uber again.'
items.reasoning: Ground-truth observations about autonomous vehicle adoption with direct customer quotes. Documents real market shift in transportation.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer reports firsthand observations of autonomous vehicles in San Francisco (Waymo, Zoox), claiming job displacement is real and accelerating. Cites customer feedback: 'never buying a car again,' 'never driving again,' 'never taking Uber again.'
items.content_html:
@EmCeeH0 @PeterDiamandis @TonyRobbins That just isn't true. You really need to visit San Francisco and see what's happening on the streets: Waymos, Zooxs, and soon Teslas are everywhere.

They are taking jobs, and they're going to come for a lot more jobs over the next three years. It's only going to accelerate from here. It might have taken a little bit of time to get here, but it's here now, and it's not just hype.

I've been interviewing Waymo customers, and they tell me over and over:

1. "I'm never buying a car again."

2. "I'm never driving again."

3. "I'm never taking an Uber again."

items.title:
What if a single line of text could generate an entire virtual world,
one that remembers what you di...
items.content:
What if a single line of text could generate an entire virtual world,
one that remembers what you did, reacts to it, and keeps evolving in real time?

Not a video.
A world with memory, physics, and consequences.

This is what @GoogleDeepMind is pushing toward, and it changes how we test, train, and plan.

items.summary: Ronald van Loon discusses Google DeepMind's work on generative world models - text-to-world systems that maintain memory, physics, and consequences unlike simple video generation.

items.title:
Congrats @Replit on this new launch.

If we're bringing AI to work wherever we are, then I'm gonna n...
items.content:
Congrats @Replit on this new launch.

If we're bringing AI to work wherever we are, then I'm gonna need a platform that brings it to my phone. 

I want to AI in ubers. I want to AI on the subway. I want to fire off tasks on a Tuesday afternoon while I walk to a friend's apartment. I want to AI anywhere that isn't superglued to my desk chair in my tiny home and that's going to be on a mobile device. 

Fun to be an investor in this company.

items.content_html:
Congrats @Replit on this new launch.

If we're bringing AI to work wherever we are, then I'm gonna need a platform that brings it to my phone.

I want to AI in ubers. I want to AI on the subway. I want to fire off tasks on a Tuesday afternoon while I walk to a friend's apartment. I want to AI anywhere that isn't superglued to my desk chair in my tiny home and that's going to be on a mobile device.

Fun to be an investor in this company.

items.content:
I'm still catching up after CES and a raft of meetings this week.

In between answering emails, I was doing some fun rap videos.Â 

Compared to Seedance 1.5 Pro, @Kling_ai 2.6 clearly wins in both audio and visuals â€” and yes, it can actually rap.

If you haven't used Kling lately, you should try it out. Now builds native audio and video in one pass. The visuals are sharper, the sound is more natural, and voice control finally fixes voice consistency.

Yesterday I asked "is Kling still king?" And my commenters said yes, and I agree.

This is the most complete audio-visual model Iâ€™ve used so far. Try it at https://t.co/wk7E6kVBhb

items.title: @RangeshUs I really haven't found smart glasses I love to wear yet. The Even Realities are close, bu...
items.content:
@RangeshUs I really haven't found smart glasses I love to wear yet. The Even Realities are close, but they don't have cameras or microphones, so you still have to have your phone close to your mouth.

We'll get there. I guess if I cared about this, the Meta Ray-Bans audio glasses are probably the best, but I want ones with displays (and the ones with displays suck).

items.content_html:
@RangeshUs I really haven't found smart glasses I love to wear yet. The Even Realities are close, but they don't have cameras or microphones, so you still have to have your phone close to your mouth.

We'll get there. I guess if I cared about this, the Meta Ray-Bans audio glasses are probably the best, but I want ones with displays (and the ones with displays suck).

items.title: @adam_x_mentis @sundayrobotics Luckily I don't have stairs in my home, except to get into the garage...
items.content:
@adam_x_mentis @sundayrobotics Luckily I don't have stairs in my home, except to get into the garage, so this robot will never be able to fully do my laundry like an Optimus or a Neo should be able to. 

My son is special needs, too, and will need a lot of help in life, and this would be perfect for him since he can do the heavy lifting of laundry, but would have a far better life with a robot that can do a bunch of things for him.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer discusses potential use case for home robots helping his special needs son with daily tasks.
items.reasoning: Personal perspective on accessibility applications for robotics, adds context to Sunday Robotics analysis.

@adam_x_mentis @sundayrobotics Luckily I don't have stairs in my home, except to get into the garage, so this robot will never be able to fully do my laundry like an Optimus or a Neo should be able to.

My son is special needs, too, and will need a lot of help in life, and this would be perfect for him since he can do the heavy lifting of laundry, but would have a far better life with a robot that can do a bunch of things for him.

items.title: If you haven't used Kling before, it takes a slight bit to figure out. You can make images, or video...
items.content:
If you haven't used Kling before, it takes a slight bit to figure out. You can make images, or videos. Either from your own pictures, or you can just start with a prompt and let it do everything. Speaking of prompts, try writing your own, but then you can have it improve your prompts.

For this video I chose just to let it do all the work, here's the prompts.

prompt1: With a 4K cinematic quality, the camera focuses on a young man striding confidently through a city street, rapping as he walks. He's dressed in streetwear, his expression cool and aloof, and the background music has a strong rhythm, with powerful drumbeats and bass that create a sense of pressure. He's rapping: "I'm on this road, never turning back, Chasing dreams, with every step I'm on track."

prompt2: On a neon-lit street, a white British man in a leather jacket was rapping. He walked along, rapping freely and confidently. He rapped: "City lights flashing while I walk my lane. Same cold streets, but I'm not the same."
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Tutorial-style post explaining how to use Kling AI for video generation, including example prompts for creating rap video content with 4K cinematic quality
items.reasoning: Practical guide with specific prompts showing Kling's capabilities, useful for practitioners but somewhat promotional in nature
items.summary_html: Tutorial-style post explaining how to use Kling AI for video generation, including example prompts for creating rap video content with 4K cinematic quality
items.content_html:
If you haven't used Kling before, it takes a slight bit to figure out. You can make images, or videos. Either from your own pictures, or you can just start with a prompt and let it do everything. Speaking of prompts, try writing your own, but then you can have it improve your prompts.

For this video I chose just to let it do all the work, here's the prompts.

prompt1: With a 4K cinematic quality, the camera focuses on a young man striding confidently through a city street, rapping as he walks. He's dressed in streetwear, his expression cool and aloof, and the background music has a strong rhythm, with powerful drumbeats and bass that create a sense of pressure. He's rapping: "I'm on this road, never turning back, Chasing dreams, with every step I'm on track."

prompt2: On a neon-lit street, a white British man in a leather jacket was rapping. He walked along, rapping freely and confidently. He rapped: "City lights flashing while I walk my lane. Same cold streets, but I'm not the same."

items.title: @Math_MntnrHZ When you use a chatbot for coding, you don't debug in a traditional sense. The debuggi...
items.content: @Math_MntnrHZ When you use a chatbot for coding, you don't debug in a traditional sense. The debugging happens behind the scenes with the chatbot running code and observing the results. On rare occasions, you should run the code yourself by building the full application, only for then sending the log to the chatbot so it can continue debugging.

items.summary_html: @Math_MntnrHZ When you use a chatbot for coding, you don't debug in a traditional sense. The debugging happens behind the scenes with the chatbot running code and observing the results. On rare occasi...
items.content_html: @Math_MntnrHZ When you use a chatbot for coding, you don't debug in a traditional sense. The debugging happens behind the scenes with the chatbot running code and observing the results. On rare occasions, you should run the code yourself by building the full application, only for then sending the log to the chatbot so it can continue debugging.

This is a police state, where they can decide to stop you, even for no reason. They can search your car, throw you in a van, and decide when to let you go.

I come from Cuba. Shithole dictatorship. Thatâ€™s exactly what they are doing here.

items.title: @gootecks @adrian_horning_ @dvassallo Iâ€™m an immigrant. Naturalized American and citizen for 12 year...
items.content:
@gootecks @adrian_horning_ @dvassallo Iâ€™m an immigrant. Naturalized American and citizen for 12 years. 

I have an accent. I speak Spanish in public with my family and friends.

My first question is, do you think I deserve to be here in the US?

The second question, assuming you think I deserve to stay, do you think I deserve to live in fear masked men will stop me or my family, throw me in the back of a van until they figure out who I am?

The third question, assuming we can agree that deporting bad people itâ€™s important, is how much government intervention are we willing to tolerate? Is this enough? Do we want even more?

We've made a ton of progress with these avatars.

â€¢ They can see you
â€¢ They can hear you
â€¢ They can ...
items.content:
We've made a ton of progress with these avatars.

â€¢ They can see you
â€¢ They can hear you
â€¢ They can talk to you
â€¢ They remember you
â€¢ They know about whatever topics you want

There's still a lot of work before they feel 100% real, but we've come a long way in the last couple of years.

If you want to give this a try, check it out here: https://t.co/nJvSezFcvX

If you add a comment with what you think are good use cases for a PAL and tag @tavus, they will pick the best ones and give you early access.

Thanks to the Tavus team for all their work helping me understand their platform and collaborating with me here.

There's still a lot of work before they feel 100% real, but we've come a long way in the last couple of years.

If you want to give this a try, check it out here: https://t.co/nJvSezFcvX

If you add a comment with what you think are good use cases for a PAL and tag @tavus, they will pick the best ones and give you early access.

Thanks to the Tavus team for all their work helping me understand their platform and collaborating with me here.

items.title:
I just saved hours per week with ONE hour and ONE button press inside Claude.

Follow this: 

1) I w...
items.content:
I just saved hours per week with ONE hour and ONE button press inside Claude.

Follow this: 

1) I went to a recent thread where I completed a task that I have to do often (ex: write newsletter headlines, edit a client email). 

2) I dictated into the thread "I'm going to turn this into a skill. Ask me a few clarifying questions so we can abstract (this one client email/this one newsletter subject line) into many.

3) Dictate replies to all questions.

4) Dictate "turn this into a Claude Skill"

5) Wait

6) Hit "Copy to Skills"

Now, for the rest of eternity, I just have to type into a conversation "write me a newsletter subject line" it will apply all of my rules and preferences and style and structure and output them in the exact way and order that I want. 

To the creator of the "Copy to Skills" button in Claude: may both sides of your pillow always be cold. May a circus of puppies trot by you all wanting a belly rub. May your USB go in the right way on your first attempt.

Follow this:

1) I went to a recent thread where I completed a task that I have to do often (ex: write newsletter headlines, edit a client email).

3) Dictate replies to all questions.

4) Dictate "turn this into a Claude Skill"

5) Wait

6) Hit "Copy to Skills"

Now, for the rest of eternity, I just have to type into a conversation "write me a newsletter subject line" it will apply all of my rules and preferences and style and structure and output them in the exact way and order that I want.

To the creator of the "Copy to Skills" button in Claude: may both sides of your pillow always be cold. May a circus of puppies trot by you all wanting a belly rub. May your USB go in the right way on your first attempt.

Text becomes the control layer.

Instead of editors or complex tooling, you can:

â†’ Add obstacles
â†’ ...
items.content:
Text becomes the control layer.

Instead of editors or complex tooling, you can:

â†’ Add obstacles
â†’ Change weather
â†’ Introduce new agents
â†’ Take control mid-simulation

Sessions persist, replay, and refine.

You inspect trajectories, spot failure modes, then iterate faster than traditional simulation stacks.

items.content:
The real breakthrough is not visuals.
Itâ€™s persistence.

This kind of generative world model:

â†’ Maintains state over time
â†’ Preserves physics and spatial layout
â†’ Lets actions compound over minutes, not frames

You are no longer prompting a clip.
You are interacting with a system that remembers.

items.title: @Tyler_Menzer @ryancbriggs You are wrong here. OpenAI, Gemini, and Anthropic absolutely have HIPAA c...
items.content:
@Tyler_Menzer @ryancbriggs You are wrong here. OpenAI, Gemini, and Anthropic absolutely have HIPAA compliant installations of their frontier models.

But the point of the post was that saying that AI cannot do something without using frontier models doesn't do much to tell us what AI can and cannot do.
